note: Cluster definitions for all Science (KS1, KS2, KS3), Biology (KS4), Chemistry (KS4), and Physics (KS4) domains. Cluster names follow NGSS/CC Math style: verb phrase + science-specific content (4-12 words). Clusters use co_teach_hints to group conceptually linked concepts. KS3 domains are large and use 4-8 clusters each to represent coherent steps in the learning journey.

clusters.cluster_name: Ask questions and make close observations of the natural world
clusters.rationale: Scientific curiosity and the habit of close observation are the entry point to all science; posing questions gives purpose to observation. Together these establish the foundational scientific disposition before any formal investigation method is introduced.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS Science and Engineering Practice 1 - Asking Questions

clusters.cluster_name: Carry out simple tests and sort findings by grouping
clusters.rationale: Simple comparative testing and grouping/sorting are the two most common KS1 enquiry types; the comparative testing method underpins fair-test thinking while sorting decisions make grouping operational. Co-teach hints link C003/C039 (testing) and C004/C044 (sorting).
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 3 - Planning and Carrying Out Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Observe changes over time and use simple equipment
clusters.rationale: Observation over time is a distinct and important KS1 enquiry type (watching plants grow, seasons change); using simple equipment such as hand lenses and rulers makes those observations more accurate. C040 and C043 are closely related process/skill versions of the same idea.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 3 - Planning and Carrying Out Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Identify patterns and draw conclusions from evidence
clusters.rationale: Noticing similarities and differences (C045) feeds directly into pattern recognition (C007), which enables drawing conclusions (C005). These three concepts form a coherent sense-making sequence that follows any KS1 investigation.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 6 - Constructing Explanations

clusters.cluster_name: Record and communicate scientific findings in different ways
clusters.rationale: Recording (C006), using secondary sources (C008), and scientific communication (C042) together encompass how pupils share and extend their science knowledge. All three involve literacy-science integration and naturally co-occur in project work.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 8 - Obtaining, Evaluating, and Communicating Information

clusters.cluster_name: Stay safe during science investigations
clusters.rationale: Sun safety is the one explicit KS1 safety rule and must be covered before any outdoor or solar observation activity. It stands alone as a focused safety cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: UK NC statutory safety requirement

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and describe common plants and their basic parts
clusters.rationale: Naming plants and identifying their external parts establishes the vocabulary and concrete referents that underpin all subsequent plant biology at KS1. Co_teach_hint links C009 and C010 directly.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Compare deciduous and evergreen trees through the seasons
clusters.rationale: Deciduous versus evergreen is a distinct observational focus that links plants to seasonal change; it is best taught during an extended observation project across the school year.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate how seeds germinate and plants grow
clusters.rationale: Germination, plant requirements, and growth from seeds/bulbs form a natural investigative sequence: pupils grow plants and test what they need to survive. All three concepts are operationally linked in the classic bean-in-a-jar investigation.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and compare animals by their group and body structure
clusters.rationale: Classifying animals into vertebrate groups and comparing their body structures provides the organising framework for all KS1 animal biology. These two concepts are naturally paired in observation and comparison activities.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

clusters.cluster_name: Classify animals by what they eat
clusters.rationale: Diet classification (herbivore, carnivore, omnivore) is a distinct conceptual lens that connects animal structure to function and later feeds into food chain work.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.B - Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Name human body parts and describe the five senses
clusters.rationale: Human body parts and the senses are typically taught together as an introduction to human biology; the senses use specific body parts and both are concrete, personal, and engaging for KS1 pupils.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe how animals grow and change through their life cycle
clusters.rationale: Animal life cycles and human growth stages are taught in parallel, both showing offspring developing into adults. Pairing them helps pupils generalise the concept across species including themselves.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Understand what animals need to survive and stay healthy
clusters.rationale: Basic survival needs (water, food, air) lead naturally to human health requirements (diet, exercise, hygiene) and the ethical attitude of caring for living things. All three share the organising idea that living things have biological needs.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Identify common materials and distinguish objects from materials
clusters.rationale: Understanding that objects are made from materials, and naming those materials, is the prerequisite for all further materials science. The object/material distinction is a key conceptual move at KS1.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Describe and compare properties of different materials
clusters.rationale: Learning property vocabulary (hard/soft, rigid/flexible, transparent/opaque) directly enables the key KS1 idea that materials are chosen for their properties. These two concepts are functionally inseparable.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate how forces can change the shape of solid materials
clusters.rationale: Physical transformation through squashing, bending, twisting and stretching is a distinct practical investigation that links materials to forces and introduces reversibility as a concept for later KS2 work.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Identify the four seasons and describe their typical weather
clusters.rationale: Naming the seasons and associating each with characteristic weather patterns are the foundational concepts of this domain; they provide the framework for all subsequent seasonal observation.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.D - Weather and Climate

clusters.cluster_name: Observe and measure how day length changes across the year
clusters.rationale: Day length variation through sunrise and sunset observation is the one quantitative element of KS1 seasonal change; recording it over time connects directly to the observation-over-time enquiry type.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.B - Earth and the Solar System

clusters.cluster_name: Classify things as living, dead, or never alive
clusters.rationale: The living/dead/never-alive classification and the life processes that define living things are the conceptual foundation of all biology; they must come first in this domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1 - From Molecules to Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Describe habitats and explain how they suit the animals that live there
clusters.rationale: Habitat concept, micro-habitats, and habitat suitability/adaptation form a coherent ecological sequence: what a habitat is, the fine-grained variety within it, and why organisms are suited to their specific habitat.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

clusters.cluster_name: Understand how plants and animals in a habitat depend on each other
clusters.rationale: Interdependence and simple food chains together explain the feeding relationships that sustain a habitat. Food chains are the concrete representation of interdependence and are best taught together.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.A - Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

clusters.cluster_name: Ask scientific questions and choose the right type of enquiry
clusters.rationale: Selecting appropriate enquiry type (including fair and comparative testing) is the gateway skill for all KS2 scientific investigation. Co_teach_hints link C001 and C002 directly.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 1 - Asking Questions; SEP 3 - Planning Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Plan investigations by identifying and controlling variables
clusters.rationale: Variable control and precision/repeat measurement are the two features that distinguish KS2 fair testing from KS1 simple testing. They are always taught together in investigation planning.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 3 - Planning and Carrying Out Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Measure systematically and record data in a variety of formats
clusters.rationale: Systematic measurement, data classification/presentation, and complex data recording form a progression from basic to advanced data-handling skills. Co_teach_hints link C001, C004, and C009 together.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 4 - Analysing and Interpreting Data

clusters.cluster_name: Draw conclusions, evaluate evidence, and communicate scientific findings
clusters.rationale: Drawing conclusions (C005), scientific reporting (C006), and causal relationship/evidence evaluation (C010) are the three sense-making and communication skills that close every enquiry cycle at KS2.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 6 - Constructing Explanations; SEP 8 - Communicating Information

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the functions of plant parts and how plants get what they need
clusters.rationale: Understanding plant part functions and requirements for life together establish the structure-function foundation for all KS2 plant biology. These two concepts are conceptually inseparable.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate water transport through plants
clusters.rationale: Water transport (demonstrable with celery/dye experiments) is a distinct, investigable process at KS2 that connects plant structure to function in a concrete, observable way.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain the complete life cycle of a flowering plant
clusters.rationale: The flowering plant life cycle, pollination, and seed dispersal are the three components of plant reproduction that together complete the life cycle narrative from flower to seed dispersal to new plant.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Understand nutrition, teeth, and digestion in humans and animals
clusters.rationale: Animal nutrition, the digestive system, and tooth types form a tightly linked cluster that traces food from ingestion through digestion. Co_teach_hints extensively link C017, C031, and C032 together.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the skeletal and muscular systems and their functions
clusters.rationale: The skeletal and muscular system is a self-contained structural topic at KS2, providing support, protection and movement, that is taught as a distinct practical unit using models and diagrams.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Construct and interpret food chains including producers and predators
clusters.rationale: Food chains with producers, consumers, predators and prey build on KS1 food chain work and connect nutrition to ecosystem relationships; taught here rather than in habitats because it flows directly from nutrition content.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.B - Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Describe human development from birth to old age
clusters.rationale: Human development and ageing is a distinct PSHE-connected science topic covering the full human life span; taught as a standalone cluster to give it appropriate curriculum time.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how the circulatory system transports nutrients and oxygen
clusters.rationale: The circulatory system and nutrient/water transport in animals are directly linked in the co_teach_hints and conceptually inseparable: the heart and blood vessels exist specifically to deliver nutrients and oxygen absorbed through digestion.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate how diet, exercise, and lifestyle affect the body
clusters.rationale: Diet, exercise, drugs and lifestyle is the health literacy component of KS2 biology; it applies the physiological knowledge from circulatory and digestive topics to personal health decisions.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Compare and classify rocks by their appearance and properties
clusters.rationale: Rock classification and soil composition are linked through the co_teach_hints (C019 and C021) and share the investigative approach of comparing physical properties; soil is formed from weathered rock particles.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.A - Earth Materials and Systems

clusters.cluster_name: Describe how fossils form and what they tell us about the past
clusters.rationale: Fossil formation is a distinct conceptual topic that connects rocks to the history of life; it provides a bridge to KS2 evolution content and is best taught as a focused narrative unit.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.A - Evidence of Common Ancestry and Diversity

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate light sources, vision, and the formation of shadows
clusters.rationale: Light and vision (we need light to see) and shadow formation (light blocked by opaque objects) are the two foundational light concepts at KS2. Co_teach_hints link C024 to C067 and C022 to C023.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.B - Electromagnetic Radiation

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how light travels in straight lines and is reflected from surfaces
clusters.rationale: The straight-line travel model explains both reflection (light bouncing off surfaces) and shadow formation; C067 is the explanatory model that underpins C023. Co_teach_hints link C023 and C067 directly.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.B - Electromagnetic Radiation

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and compare contact and non-contact forces
clusters.rationale: Contact versus non-contact forces is the organising framework for this domain; friction as a contact force (C027) is the most investigable example at KS1/early KS2. Co_teach_hints link C027 to C025.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate the properties and uses of magnets
clusters.rationale: Magnetic properties (attraction, repulsion, poles, magnetic materials) constitute a distinct investigable topic with clear KS2 practical activities; magnetism as a non-contact force connects to C025.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Classify living things and use classification keys
clusters.rationale: Dichotomous classification keys and the idea that living things can be grouped using many different criteria are the twin classification skills of this domain; they are always taught together.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

clusters.cluster_name: Apply the formal biological classification system including microorganisms
clusters.rationale: Formal biological classification (micro-organisms, plants, animals, fungi) and microorganisms as a group are linked in the co_teach_hints (C058, C059) and together extend KS1 classification into a more scientific taxonomy.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

clusters.cluster_name: Compare the life cycles of different types of animals
clusters.rationale: Comparative life cycles and reproduction in plants and animals are linked concepts that together show the diversity of reproductive strategies across living things. They build directly on KS1 life cycle work.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Analyse how environmental change affects habitats and living things
clusters.rationale: Environmental change and its impact on organisms connects ecological knowledge to contemporary issues such as habitat loss; co_teach_hints link C030 to C059 (microorganisms playing a role in environmental change).
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and describe the three states of matter by their properties
clusters.rationale: The three states of matter and their observable properties establish the foundational classification that enables understanding of changes of state and the water cycle.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain changes of state and the water cycle using evidence
clusters.rationale: Changes of state and the water cycle are directly linked in the co_teach_hints (C036 co-teaches with C035); evaporation and condensation are both change-of-state processes and key water cycle mechanisms.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.C - The Role of Water in Earth's Surface Processes

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate vibration as the cause of sound and how sound travels
clusters.rationale: Vibration as the source of all sounds and transmission through a medium are the two foundational sound concepts; they explain both how sound is made and how it reaches our ears.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.A - Wave Properties

clusters.cluster_name: Explore how pitch and volume relate to the properties of sound sources
clusters.rationale: Pitch (related to vibrating object features) and volume (related to vibration strength/amplitude) are the two key sound qualities pupils investigate at KS2. Co_teach_hints link C039 with C040 and C037.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.A - Wave Properties

clusters.cluster_name: Build and describe series electrical circuits and their components
clusters.rationale: Series circuits and conductors/insulators are the entry-point electricity concepts at KS2; co_teach_hints link C042 directly to C041 because conductors/insulators are tested within a simple circuit.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate how voltage affects circuit components and use circuit diagrams
clusters.rationale: Voltage/cell effects on circuit brightness/volume and standard circuit symbols/diagrams are taught together because circuit diagrams are the tool for recording and communicating voltage investigations. Co_teach_hints link C068 to C041 and C043.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Compare materials using an extended range of physical properties
clusters.rationale: Extended material properties (hardness, solubility, transparency, conductivity) build on KS1 basic properties and provide the investigative framework for all KS2 materials work.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate dissolving and how to separate mixtures
clusters.rationale: Dissolving and separation techniques are practically linked: pupils dissolve a substance and then use evaporation, filtration or sieving to recover it, demonstrating that dissolving is reversible.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Distinguish reversible changes from irreversible chemical changes
clusters.rationale: Reversible and irreversible changes are the conceptual culmination of KS2 materials work; co_teach_hints link C051 to C049 and C050. The distinction between physical and chemical change is foundational for KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the solar system and the relative positions of planets
clusters.rationale: The solar system structure and the Moon's orbit as Earth's satellite are the spatial framework concepts for this domain. Co_teach_hints link C054 and C052 directly.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.B - Earth and the Solar System

clusters.cluster_name: Explain day and night using a model of Earth's rotation
clusters.rationale: Earth's rotation and its cause of day and night is the key explanatory model of the domain; it requires the solar system structure from the introduction cluster and directly addresses the common misconception that the Sun moves around Earth.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.B - Earth and the Solar System

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how gravity and resistance forces affect motion
clusters.rationale: Gravity and resistance forces (air resistance, water resistance, friction) are co-taught (co_teach_hints link C055 and C056) because they act in opposition: gravity pulls objects down while resistance slows their fall.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate how levers, pulleys and gears act as force multipliers
clusters.rationale: Mechanisms as force multipliers is a distinct practical investigation cluster at KS2 that applies force understanding to simple machines; it introduces the efficiency trade-off concept that continues at KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Understand how fossils provide evidence that living things change over time
clusters.rationale: Fossils as evidence of change over time is the evidential foundation for evolution; co_teach_hints link C063 to C066, establishing a logical starting point before variation, adaptation and natural selection are introduced.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.A - Evidence of Common Ancestry and Diversity

clusters.cluster_name: Explain variation in offspring and how features are inherited
clusters.rationale: Variation in offspring is the genetic prerequisite for understanding natural selection; it introduces the idea that offspring are similar but not identical to parents, setting up adaptation and evolution.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS3.B - Variation of Traits

clusters.cluster_name: Describe adaptation and explain how it can lead to evolution
clusters.rationale: Adaptation and evolution are directly linked in the co_teach_hints (C066 co-teaches with C065); together they form the core Darwin narrative that variation + adaptation over geological time = evolutionary change.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.B - Natural Selection; LS4.C - Adaptation

clusters.cluster_name: Compare the structure of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells
clusters.rationale: Eukaryotic/prokaryotic structure and cell specialisation/differentiation together establish the cell as the fundamental unit of life in its varied forms; differentiation builds directly on structural knowledge.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain mitosis, cell division, and transport across cell membranes
clusters.rationale: Mitosis and membrane transport (diffusion, osmosis, active transport) are co-taught via co_teach_hints (C003 links to C004); both are essential cell-level processes and are typically covered in the same unit.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain enzyme action in digestion and the digestive system
clusters.rationale: Enzymes and digestion is the biochemical entry point for GCSE organisation, connecting cell biology (enzyme structure/active site) to the organ-system level of the digestive system.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the structure and function of the heart and circulatory system
clusters.rationale: The heart as a double pump and the pulmonary/systemic circulation is the central cardiovascular concept at GCSE; it integrates structural knowledge with physiological function.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain transpiration and nutrient transport in plants
clusters.rationale: Transpiration and the xylem/phloem transport system in plants mirrors the animal circulatory system and completes the organisational level of study; typically taught alongside heart/circulation for contrast.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe pathogen types and how communicable diseases spread
clusters.rationale: Pathogens and communicable disease provide the disease framework before immune response is studied; understanding transmission precedes understanding how the body defends against pathogens.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.A - Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how the immune system responds and how vaccines provide protection
clusters.rationale: Immune response and vaccination directly follow pathogen knowledge; understanding antibody production and the role of lymphocytes provides the biological mechanism behind vaccination programmes.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain photosynthesis and aerobic and anaerobic respiration
clusters.rationale: Photosynthesis and respiration are directly co-taught (co_teach_hints link C010 and C011 mutually); they are the two energy transformation processes in living things and form the conceptual core of bioenergetics.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the nervous system and explain reflex arc responses
clusters.rationale: The nervous system and reflex arcs introduce the neural control pathway that underpins all rapid homeostatic responses; it establishes the receptor-coordinator-effector model used throughout this domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Explain blood glucose regulation and the role of hormones in diabetes
clusters.rationale: Blood glucose regulation by insulin and glucagon is the prime GCSE example of hormonal homeostasis; its clinical context (Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes) provides real-world relevance.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe DNA structure and explain how genes code for proteins
clusters.rationale: DNA structure and protein synthesis is the molecular foundation of all inheritance content at GCSE; it must precede Mendelian genetics and evolution because genes are defined in terms of DNA.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS3.A - Inheritance of Traits

clusters.cluster_name: Apply Mendelian genetics to predict inheritance patterns
clusters.rationale: Mendelian genetics with Punnett squares and dominant/recessive alleles is the quantitative genetics skill of GCSE biology; it applies molecular knowledge from DNA/protein synthesis to inheritance prediction.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS3.B - Variation of Traits

clusters.cluster_name: Explain evolution by natural selection and evaluate supporting evidence
clusters.rationale: Evolution by natural selection at GCSE requires the full mechanistic explanation (variation, heritability, selection pressure, differential reproduction) underpinned by the genetics knowledge from the two preceding clusters.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.B - Natural Selection

clusters.cluster_name: Describe ecosystem structure and how organisms depend on each other
clusters.rationale: Ecosystem interdependence (biotic and abiotic factors, food webs, carbon and water cycles) is the conceptual entry point for GCSE ecology before human impact is considered.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.A - Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate the impact of human activity on biodiversity and ecosystems
clusters.rationale: Biodiversity and human impact applies ecosystem knowledge to real conservation challenges; it is the culminating applied topic of GCSE biology, connecting back to all earlier ecological understanding.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

CH-KS4-D001.domain_name: Atomic Structure and the Periodic Table

clusters.cluster_name: Describe atomic structure using subatomic particles
clusters.rationale: Atomic structure with protons, neutrons and electrons is the essential foundation for all chemistry at GCSE; it must precede electronic configuration and bonding.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain electronic configuration and predict periodic trends
clusters.rationale: Electronic configuration explains the arrangement of the Periodic Table and enables prediction of chemical properties and reactivity trends across groups and periods.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

CH-KS4-D002.domain_name: Bonding, Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain ionic bonding and the properties of giant ionic lattices
clusters.rationale: Ionic bonding (electron transfer, lattice structure, high melting point, conductivity when molten) is typically taught first because its electrostatic model is more concrete. Co_teach_hints link C003 and C004.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain covalent bonding and the properties of molecular structures
clusters.rationale: Covalent bonding (electron sharing, simple molecules, giant covalent structures) builds on ionic bonding to complete the GCSE bonding framework and explains properties of non-metal compounds.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Apply the mole concept and stoichiometry to calculate reacting quantities
clusters.rationale: The mole and stoichiometric calculations are the mathematical foundation of quantitative chemistry; they must precede yield and atom economy calculations. Co_teach_hints link C005 and C006.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate percentage yield and atom economy for chemical reactions
clusters.rationale: Percentage yield and atom economy apply mole calculations to real industrial chemistry contexts, evaluating reaction efficiency and sustainability. Co_teach_hints link C006 to C005.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Use the reactivity series to predict displacement and oxidation reactions
clusters.rationale: The reactivity series and displacement reactions provide a predictive framework for chemical changes involving metals; co_teach_hints link C007 and C008, as electrolysis is often used to extract reactive metals.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain electrolysis and its industrial applications
clusters.rationale: Electrolysis uses ionic knowledge and extends chemical changes into electrochemistry; its industrial applications (aluminium extraction, electroplating) provide real-world context.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain exothermic and endothermic reactions using bond energies
clusters.rationale: Exothermic and endothermic reactions with bond energy calculations is the sole concept in this domain; the single cluster covers the energy landscape of chemical reactions at GCSE.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

CH-KS4-D006.domain_name: Rate and Extent of Chemical Change

clusters.cluster_name: Explain reaction rates using collision theory and identify affecting factors
clusters.rationale: Collision theory as the mechanistic explanation for rate of reaction is the entry point for this domain; it connects particle model knowledge to the practical investigation of concentration, temperature, surface area and catalysts.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe reversible reactions and dynamic equilibrium
clusters.rationale: Reversible reactions and dynamic equilibrium build on reaction rate understanding to introduce the idea that some reactions can run in both directions and reach a balanced state; this is a conceptually distinct topic from rates.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe hydrocarbons in crude oil and explain fractional distillation
clusters.rationale: Hydrocarbons and crude oil is the sole concept in this domain at GCSE; it covers the origin, composition and separation of crude oil and the societal and environmental implications of fossil fuels.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Apply chemical analysis techniques to identify and test unknown substances
clusters.rationale: Chemical analysis and identification techniques (flame tests, gas tests, precipitation, chromatography) is the single concept in this domain and is best taught as a practical skills cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain the greenhouse effect and evaluate the evidence for climate change
clusters.rationale: The greenhouse effect and climate change is the single concept in this domain; it applies atmospheric chemistry knowledge to one of the most significant socio-scientific issues of the era.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.D - Weather and Climate

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate environmental impact using life cycle assessment and sustainable chemistry
clusters.rationale: Life cycle assessment and sustainable chemistry is the single concept in this domain; it provides the analytical tool for evaluating the environmental cost of products across their entire life span.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS3.C - Human Impacts on Earth Systems

clusters.cluster_name: Describe energy stores and explain how energy is transferred between systems
clusters.rationale: Energy stores and transfers provide the organising framework for all KS4 physics energy topics; identifying kinetic, gravitational potential, elastic, thermal and chemical stores underpins all subsequent energy calculations.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.A - Definitions of Energy

clusters.cluster_name: Apply specific heat capacity and latent heat to calculate energy changes
clusters.rationale: Specific heat capacity and latent heat are the two quantitative energy calculations for thermal processes at GCSE; they directly extend energy store/transfer knowledge into measurable quantities.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Apply Ohm's law to calculate current, potential difference and resistance
clusters.rationale: Current, potential difference and resistance with Ohm's law is the foundational circuit calculation skill at GCSE; it must precede power calculations and AC/mains electricity.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate electrical power and explain mains electricity and safety
clusters.rationale: Electrical power calculations and mains electricity (AC, frequency, live/neutral/earth wires) build directly on V, I and R relationships and connect circuit physics to domestic electrical safety.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Apply the particle model to explain density, states of matter and gas laws
clusters.rationale: The particle model, density and gas laws constitute the single GCSE physics concept in this domain; the particle model explanation of state properties and gas pressure/volume/temperature relationships is a unified topic.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Describe radioactive decay and the properties of nuclear radiation
clusters.rationale: Radioactive decay and alpha/beta/gamma radiation properties are the entry concepts for nuclear physics at GCSE; they provide the factual framework before the deeper concepts of fission and fusion are explored.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.C - Nuclear Processes

clusters.cluster_name: Explain nuclear fission and fusion and their applications
clusters.rationale: Nuclear fission (chain reactions, nuclear reactors) and fusion (stellar energy, future power) apply radioactive decay knowledge to the most significant nuclear energy technologies; they are naturally paired as opposing processes.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.C - Nuclear Processes

clusters.cluster_name: Apply Newton's three laws of motion to analyse forces and acceleration
clusters.rationale: Newton's laws of motion are the foundational mechanics framework at GCSE; they must precede momentum and impulse because Newton's second law connects force to rate of change of momentum.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Apply conservation of momentum to analyse collisions and impulse
clusters.rationale: Momentum and impulse extend Newton's second law into conserved quantity reasoning; conservation of momentum in collisions is a key GCSE higher tier skill with important safety applications.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Describe wave properties and calculate wave speed, frequency and wavelength
clusters.rationale: Wave properties (amplitude, frequency, wavelength, speed) and the wave equation are the quantitative foundation for all wave physics at GCSE; they apply to both transverse and longitudinal waves.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.A - Wave Properties

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the electromagnetic spectrum and explain its uses and hazards
clusters.rationale: The electromagnetic spectrum applies the wave model to the full range of EM radiation from radio waves to gamma rays; its uses and hazards for each region are a key socio-scientific application of wave physics.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.B - Electromagnetic Radiation

clusters.cluster_name: Explain the motor effect and electromagnetic induction
clusters.rationale: The motor effect and electromagnetic induction are the two fundamental electromagnetic phenomena at GCSE; they are complementary (one converts electrical to mechanical energy, the other converts mechanical to electrical) and are always taught together.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how transformers work and their role in the National Grid
clusters.rationale: Transformers and the National Grid apply electromagnetic induction to the practical problem of efficient long-distance electricity transmission; the transformer equation connects voltage ratios to turns ratios.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the life cycle of stars from nebula to remnant
clusters.rationale: The life cycle of stars provides the astrophysical context for understanding nuclear fusion as the energy source of stars and explains the origin of heavy elements in the universe.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.A - The Universe and Its Stars

clusters.cluster_name: Explain red-shift as evidence for the expanding universe and the Big Bang
clusters.rationale: Red-shift and the Big Bang theory are the observational and theoretical conclusions of space physics at GCSE; red-shift evidence is the key empirical argument for the expanding universe model.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.A - The Universe and Its Stars

clusters.cluster_name: Understand how scientific knowledge is built, tested and revised over time
clusters.rationale: The nature of science (theories evolve with evidence, peer review ensures objectivity) is the conceptual foundation for all working scientifically at KS3. Co_teach_hints strongly link C001, C004 and C005.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 7 - Engaging in Argument from Evidence

clusters.cluster_name: Ask scientific questions, make predictions and design investigations
clusters.rationale: Questioning, prediction, variable identification and experimental design form the planning stage of any investigation; they are always taught together as a sequence. Co_teach_hints link C007 and C021.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 1 - Asking Questions; SEP 3 - Planning Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Use laboratory equipment safely and apply appropriate techniques
clusters.rationale: Risk evaluation, laboratory techniques, and sampling methods are the practical safety and skills cluster; they are taught in context across all KS3 practical work but need explicit introduction at the start of KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 3 - Planning and Carrying Out Investigations

clusters.cluster_name: Measure accurately, record data and use SI units and scientific equations
clusters.rationale: Measurement, SI units and scientific equations are the quantitative skills that underpin all KS3 data collection; co_teach_hints link C022 to C015 and C018, and C024 to C010 and C015.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 5 - Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking

clusters.cluster_name: Present data, identify patterns and apply statistical analysis
clusters.rationale: Data presentation (tables, graphs), pattern identification and statistical analysis form a coherent data-handling cluster. Co_teach_hints extensively link C025 with C016, C017 and C002.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 4 - Analysing and Interpreting Data

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate accuracy, precision and sources of error in scientific investigations
clusters.rationale: Accuracy/precision, repeatability/reproducibility, method reliability and error analysis together constitute the quality-assessment skills of KS3 science. Co_teach_hints link C002, C013, C020 and C025.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 4 - Analysing and Interpreting Data

clusters.cluster_name: Draw valid conclusions, use mathematical calculations and raise further questions
clusters.rationale: Mathematical calculation in context, drawing conclusions, explaining results against predictions, and identifying further questions close the inquiry cycle. Co_teach_hints link C015 to C022/C024, and C021 to C007.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS SEP 6 - Constructing Explanations; SEP 8 - Communicating Information

SC-KS3-D002.domain_name: Biology - Structure and Function of Living Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Describe cell structure and observe cells using a light microscope
clusters.rationale: Cell structure, microscopy skills, and organelle functions form the practical entry point for KS3 biology; using the microscope to see real cells makes the abstract organelle functions concrete.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Compare plant and animal cells and explain the biological hierarchy
clusters.rationale: Comparing plant/animal cells, understanding unicellular organisms, and tracing the cell-to-organism hierarchy are closely linked. Co_teach_hints link C029 to C026/C028/C031, and C032 to C026/C028/C031.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe diffusion and explain its role in moving substances into and out of cells
clusters.rationale: Diffusion is a gateway concept linking chemistry (particle model) to biology (cell transport); its extensive co_teach_hints (C033, C038, C040, C042-C045, C048) show it underpins respiratory, digestive, and circulatory system understanding.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the skeleton, muscles and joints and explain how they produce movement
clusters.rationale: Skeletal structure, biomechanics and antagonistic muscles are tightly co-taught (C034 links to C033/C035) and together explain the musculoskeletal system as a lever system.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Understand the components of a balanced diet and the consequences of poor nutrition
clusters.rationale: Balanced diet, energy requirements, dietary imbalances and gut bacteria are all aspects of nutrition that co-teach (C036 links to C037-C042); teaching them together allows real-world dietary analysis.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Explain digestion and the role of enzymes in breaking down food
clusters.rationale: Digestive system organs, enzyme action, and plant nutrition form the digestion/nutrition cluster. C040 (enzymes) co-teaches with C039 (digestive system), and C042 (plant nutrition) contrasts autotrophic and heterotrophic nutrition.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the gas exchange system and explain the mechanism of breathing
clusters.rationale: Gas exchange system structure, the pressure-model of breathing, impacts (exercise/asthma/smoking) and plant stomata together cover respiration at the organ-system level. Co_teach_hints link C043-C046.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.A - Structure and Function

clusters.cluster_name: Describe human and plant reproduction and explain the role of the placenta
clusters.rationale: Human reproduction, placenta function, plant reproduction, and drug effects on the fetus form the reproduction and health cluster for KS3 biology; C048 (placenta) is naturally paired with C047 (human reproduction).
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.B - Growth and Development of Organisms

clusters.cluster_name: Explain photosynthesis and why it is fundamental to life on Earth
clusters.rationale: The photosynthesis equation, its central importance to almost all life, and leaf adaptations form the introduction cluster. Co_teach_hints link C051 and C052 directly; C053 (leaf adaptations) is the structural counterpart.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Compare aerobic and anaerobic respiration and explain their roles in organisms
clusters.rationale: Aerobic respiration, anaerobic respiration and their comparison are tightly co-taught (C054 links to C055; C056 links to C054/C055); together they complete the energy release side of the photosynthesis-respiration cycle.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS1.C - Organisation for Matter and Energy Flow

clusters.cluster_name: Describe how organisms depend on each other in ecosystems through food webs
clusters.rationale: Ecosystem interdependence and food webs are directly co-taught (C058 links to C057) and form the conceptual entry point for ecological relationships at KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.A - Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate the importance of pollination for food security and ecosystems
clusters.rationale: Pollination and food security is the applied ecology concept linking plant reproduction to human food supply; co_teach_hints connect it to both ecosystem interdependence and biodiversity.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.A - Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems

clusters.cluster_name: Analyse how organisms interact with and affect their environment
clusters.rationale: Environmental interactions (how organisms both affect and are affected by their environment) bridge ecosystem structure to the genetics/evolution domain; co_teach_hints link it to ecosystem interdependence and natural selection.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS2.C - Ecosystem Dynamics, Functioning, and Resilience

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how genetic information is inherited using a model of DNA
clusters.rationale: Heredity, the DNA model (chromosomes and genes), and the history of its discovery form the introduction to genetics at KS3. Co_teach_hints link C061 to C062 and C064.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS3.A - Inheritance of Traits

clusters.cluster_name: Describe continuous and discontinuous variation within a species
clusters.rationale: Variation types (continuous like height vs discontinuous like blood group) is the essential bridge between inheritance and natural selection; it must be understood before selection pressures can be applied.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS3.B - Variation of Traits

clusters.cluster_name: Explain natural selection and how adaptation can lead to extinction
clusters.rationale: Natural selection and adaptation/extinction are directly co-taught (C065 links to C066); together they complete the Darwinian narrative from variation through selection to evolutionary outcome.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.B - Natural Selection; LS4.C - Adaptation

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate the importance of biodiversity and the threats to it
clusters.rationale: Biodiversity and gene banks is the culminating applied concept of the genetics/evolution domain; it connects evolution theory to contemporary conservation challenges and policy.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS LS4.D - Biodiversity and Humans

SC-KS3-D006.domain_name: Chemistry - The Particulate Nature of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the particle model and explain properties of solids, liquids and gases
clusters.rationale: The particle model and three states of matter together establish the foundational model for all KS3 chemistry; they are inseparable as the model exists precisely to explain state properties.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain changes of state and gas pressure using the particle model
clusters.rationale: Gas pressure (particle collisions with container walls) and changes of state (particles gaining/losing enough energy to overcome forces) apply the particle model to explain two key phenomena. Co_teach_hints link C070 to C068/C069.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Describe atoms, elements and compounds using the Dalton model
clusters.rationale: The Dalton atomic model and the distinctions between atoms, elements and compounds form the conceptual entry point for all KS3 chemistry classification; they must precede symbols, formulae and separation.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Use chemical symbols and apply IUPAC naming to elements and compounds
clusters.rationale: Chemical nomenclature and symbols/formulae are the language tools of chemistry; co_teach_hints link C074 to C023 and C073, as symbols are learned alongside naming conventions.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Distinguish pure substances from mixtures and apply separation techniques
clusters.rationale: Pure substances, mixtures, separation techniques and identifying pure substances form a tightly co-taught cluster. Co_teach_hints link C076-C077-C079-C080 extensively; all involve the practical application of filtration, distillation and chromatography.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain diffusion in chemistry and conservation of mass in changes
clusters.rationale: Conservation of mass and diffusion in chemical contexts extend the particle model into quantitative reasoning; both underpin understanding of chemical equations and reaction stoichiometry.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain reactions as atom rearrangement and write chemical equations
clusters.rationale: The conceptual model (reactions rearrange atoms without creating/destroying matter) and its symbolic representation (chemical equations) are the foundation of all chemical reaction understanding. Co_teach_hints link C081 and C082.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Identify and describe different types of chemical reactions
clusters.rationale: Types of reaction (combustion, thermal decomposition, oxidation, displacement) and catalysts are related through co_teach_hints (C083 lists C088); understanding reaction types requires knowing what speeds them up.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate acids and alkalis using the pH scale and neutralisation
clusters.rationale: Acids/alkalis, pH, acid-metal reactions and neutralisation are tightly co-taught (C084 links to C085/C086/C087; C085 links to C084/C086/C087) and form a coherent practical investigation sequence with indicators and neutralisation experiments.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain energy changes in chemical reactions and changes of state
clusters.rationale: Energy in state changes and exothermic/endothermic reactions are directly co-taught (C090 links to C089); together they introduce the energy dimension of all chemical processes, connecting to the physics energy domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

SC-KS3-D009.domain_name: Chemistry - The Periodic Table and Materials

clusters.cluster_name: Describe how Mendeleev organised the Periodic Table and explain its structure
clusters.rationale: Mendeleev's periodic table and its structure (periods, groups, metals, non-metals) form the historical and structural introduction to the Periodic Table before element properties and reactions are studied.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Compare properties of metals and non-metals and predict their reactions
clusters.rationale: Element properties, prediction of reaction patterns from the Periodic Table, and metal/non-metal property comparison are tightly co-taught. C094 co-teaches with C091/C092/C093/C095.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain the reactivity series and how it determines metal extraction methods
clusters.rationale: Oxide acidity, the reactivity series, and metal extraction using carbon reduction are co-taught (C096 links to C097/C098; C097 links to C098); they form the applied chemistry of metals sequence at KS3.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the properties and uses of ceramics, polymers and composites
clusters.rationale: Material types (ceramics, polymers, composites) is the materials science application cluster linking property knowledge to engineering use; co_teach_hints connect it to element properties and metal extraction.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the composition and structure of the Earth
clusters.rationale: Earth composition and Earth structure (crust, mantle, core) are directly co-taught and provide the physical geography foundation for the rock cycle and Earth resources.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.A - Earth Materials and Systems

clusters.cluster_name: Explain the rock cycle and the formation of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks
clusters.rationale: The rock cycle is the dynamic Earth process that connects Earth structure to rock types; it explains how the same material is recycled through different rock forms over geological time.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.A - Earth Materials and Systems

clusters.cluster_name: Analyse the carbon cycle and its relationship to the atmosphere
clusters.rationale: The carbon cycle and atmospheric composition are directly co-taught (C104 links to C105 and vice versa); understanding atmospheric CO2 as part of the carbon cycle is the prerequisite for understanding climate change.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS2.D - Weather and Climate

clusters.cluster_name: Evaluate Earth as a source of finite resources and the importance of recycling
clusters.rationale: Earth resources and recycling is the sustainability application concept for this domain; it applies geological knowledge to the real-world challenge of resource management.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS3.C - Human Impacts on Earth Systems

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how human carbon dioxide production causes climate change
clusters.rationale: Climate change as a consequence of human CO2 production is the culminating applied topic of the Earth and atmosphere domain; it connects carbon cycle knowledge to global environmental impact.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS3.D - Global Climate Change

clusters.cluster_name: Compare food energy values and understand fuel costs and power ratings
clusters.rationale: Food energy, power ratings, energy transfer amounts and fuel costs are the everyday-context entry cluster for KS3 energy; they make the abstract concept of energy concrete and personally relevant before formal energy conservation is introduced.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.A - Definitions of Energy

clusters.cluster_name: Describe different energy resources and evaluate their environmental impact
clusters.rationale: Energy resources (fossil fuels, renewables, nuclear) connects energy physics to societal and environmental decision-making; co_teach_hints link it to climate change (C106) and fuel costs (C110).
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS3.A - Natural Resources

clusters.cluster_name: Explain thermal equilibrium, heat transfer processes and simple machines
clusters.rationale: Simple machines (force-distance trade-off), thermal equilibrium (heat flow and insulators) and energy transfer processes (motion, gravity, combustion) are co-taught via extensive co_teach_hints and together cover the mechanisms of energy transfer.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Apply conservation of energy to describe energy changes in systems
clusters.rationale: Energy conservation, describing energy changes in systems over time, and physical mechanisms as energy changers are the formal physics conclusion of the energy domain; together they constitute the law of conservation of energy in practice.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate speed and represent motion on distance-time graphs
clusters.rationale: Speed calculation, distance-time graphs and relative motion form the kinematics introduction; co_teach_hints link C119 to C118/C120/C122. These are always taught together as the quantitative description of motion.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Describe forces as interactions and use force diagrams to represent them
clusters.rationale: Force concept, force arrow diagrams, balanced/unbalanced forces and measuring in newtons form the foundational force representation skills. Co_teach_hints strongly link C122 to C119/C121/C123.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Investigate contact forces including friction, resistance and deformation
clusters.rationale: Contact forces (friction/resistance/deformation), Hooke's Law and work/energy when deformed are co-taught (C127 links to C125/C128; C128 links to C125/C127); they form the practical force investigation sequence using springs and friction surfaces.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Describe non-contact forces including gravity, magnetism and electrostatics
clusters.rationale: Non-contact forces (gravity, magnetic, electrostatic) acting at a distance are a distinct conceptual category; co_teach_hints link C129 to C121/C122/C123 and it connects to the electromagnetism domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain pressure in fluids including liquid pressure and atmospheric pressure
clusters.rationale: Atmospheric pressure, liquid pressure/upthrust and pressure as force per unit area are directly co-taught (C130 links to C131/C132; C132 links to C130/C131); pressure in fluids is a unified sub-topic within forces.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Analyse moments, equilibrium and how forces cause changes in motion
clusters.rationale: Moments (turning effect), equilibrium with opposing forces, and forces causing changes in motion are the culminating mechanics concepts. Co_teach_hints link C124 to C125/C127/C131/C133/C134, and C133 to C120-C124/C132/C134.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.A - Forces and Motion

clusters.cluster_name: Understand how waves transfer energy and distinguish sound from light waves
clusters.rationale: Water waves as a model, waves transferring energy/information, and the comparison of light vs matter waves establish the wave concept before specific wave types are studied. Co_teach_hints link C135 to C140/C141.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.A - Wave Properties

clusters.cluster_name: Describe sound wave properties including pitch, volume, echo and auditory range
clusters.rationale: Sound frequency, properties (echoes, reflection, absorption), production through vibration and auditory range form the complete sound waves cluster. Co_teach_hints link C136 to C137/C138/C139/C143.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.A - Wave Properties

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how light travels and interacts with transparent and opaque materials
clusters.rationale: Light properties (speed in vacuum), transmission/absorption/scattering, and light causing chemical/electrical effects are co-taught (C143 links to C142/C145). Together they cover the energy aspects of light.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.B - Electromagnetic Radiation

clusters.cluster_name: Apply the ray model to explain reflection, refraction and the human eye
clusters.rationale: The ray model and colour/frequency are the geometric and quantitative aspects of light; C144 (ray model for mirrors, refraction, lenses, the eye) co-teaches with C143 and C138, and C146 (colour from frequency) completes the light spectrum picture.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS4.B - Electromagnetic Radiation

clusters.cluster_name: Describe electric current, potential difference and resistance in circuits
clusters.rationale: Current, potential difference, resistance and conductors/insulators are the four foundational electrical quantities; they are always taught together using ammeters and voltmeters in practical circuit investigations.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Compare series and parallel circuits and explain how components behave
clusters.rationale: Series and parallel circuits with current behaviour is a distinct practical topic requiring hands-on circuit building; co_teach_hints link it to current/PD/resistance, making it the applied circuit design cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.B - Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer

clusters.cluster_name: Explain static electricity and the concept of electric fields
clusters.rationale: Static electricity and electric fields are co-taught (C152 links to C153); together they introduce the field concept that unifies electric and magnetic phenomena in the next cluster.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe magnetic poles and fields including Earth's magnetic field
clusters.rationale: Magnetic poles, magnetic fields (with field lines) and Earth's magnetism are co-taught (C154 links to C155/C156; C155 links to C153/C154/C156); they form a natural sub-unit on magnetism before electromagnetism.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain electromagnetism and the motor effect in electric motors
clusters.rationale: Electromagnetism (the magnetic effect of current) and basic motor principles is the culminating concept of this domain; co_teach_hints link it to all electricity and magnetism concepts in the domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Describe similarities and differences between states using the particle model
clusters.rationale: State properties, particle arrangements explaining those properties, and atoms/molecules as the particles form the structural foundation; co_teach_hints link C159 to C163 and C163 to C159/C160/C161.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Explain Brownian motion and diffusion as evidence for particle movement
clusters.rationale: Brownian motion and diffusion driven by concentration differences are co-taught (co_teach_hints link C160 and C161 extensively); both provide observable evidence for particle motion in real systems.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.A - Structure and Properties of Matter

clusters.cluster_name: Distinguish physical changes from chemical changes and explain conservation of mass
clusters.rationale: Physical changes and the chemical vs physical change distinction are directly co-taught (C162 links to C158); both require reference to mass conservation, connecting this domain to the chemical reactions domain.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS1.B - Chemical Reactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain how temperature affects particle motion and the concept of internal energy
clusters.rationale: Temperature's effect on particles and internal energy are directly co-taught (C166 co-teaches with C160/C161/C163/C165); together they link temperature as a macroscopic measurement to the microscopic particle model.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS3.A - Definitions of Energy

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the solar system, galaxies and the structure of the universe
clusters.rationale: Solar system structure (Sun as a star, other stars, galaxies, universe structure) is the spatial context for all space physics; it establishes scale before gravitational and orbital concepts are explored.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.A - The Universe and Its Stars

clusters.cluster_name: Calculate weight using gravity and explain how gravitational field strength varies
clusters.rationale: Gravity force (W = mg), weight calculation, and varying gravitational field strength on different bodies are co-taught (C167 links to C168/C169; C168 links to C167/C169/C170); they ground space physics in quantitative force reasoning.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS PS2.B - Types of Interactions

clusters.cluster_name: Explain seasons and day length using a model of Earth's motion
clusters.rationale: Earth's seasons, axial tilt and day length variation require a 3D spatial model of Earth's orbital motion; this extends KS2 day/night understanding to the more complex seasonal phenomenon.
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.B - Earth and the Solar System

clusters.cluster_name: Describe the light year as a unit of distance and explain its astronomical significance
clusters.rationale: The light year connects the speed of light from the waves domain to the scale of the universe; co_teach_hints link it to C142 (light speed) and C169/C170 (solar system structure and Earth's motion).
clusters.inspired_by: NGSS ESS1.A - The Universe and Its Stars
